Population growth

Projection model parameters, population recorded in historical censuses (1976, 1987 and 2005), projected population (2005, 2010, 2015 and 2020) and population density, in the UNB, are presented in Table 8. Historical censuses recorded 750,346 inhabitants (39 ) in April 1976, 1,232,447 inhabitants (64 ) in April 1987 and 2,559,390 inhabitants (133 ) in November 2005. Based on these historical censuses89, 90–91projected populations in December of the years 2005, 2010, 2015 and 2020 are respectively 2,596,668 inhabitants (135 ), 3,059,995 inhabitants (159 ), 3,567,045 inhabitants (185 ) and 4,117,819 inhabitants (214 ). Based on the 1976 and 2005 censuses, the interannual population growth rate in Nyong is 8.1 . This rate is almost double that of Cameroon over the same period (4.3 ), and is lower than those of the country’s two main cities, Yaounde (Mfoundi, 16.9 ) and Douala (12.2% ). According to projections, in 2020, the city of Yaounde alone contains 80.1% of the entire population of UNB. The city of Yaounde can therefore be considered as the main factor responsible for the higher growth rate of the UNB compared to the national rate. The city hosts the main institutions of the country with the populations tasked to carry out administrative functions. These institutions and the personnels indirectly create the demand and possibilities for activities such as real estate, agriculture, education, trade, etc. All this explains the deforestation and expansion of impervious and agricultural surface in and around Yaounde, as mentioned above.

This suggests that the Mefou is the origin of the enrichment of the Nyong (Olama and Mbalmayo) compared to its tributaries. The high densification and growth of the population in Yaounde, as well as the corresponding deforestation and development of impervious and agricultural surface, induce a production of waste and wastewater. Discussion

Disentangling hydroclimatic and anthropogenic influence on river hydrology/chemistry

In the UNB, AT increases significantly (p < 0.01) in the long term at monthly, interseasonal and interannual scales. The interannual increase is distributed in descending order: +2.2 °C/100 years for Mbalmayo area, + 2.1 °C/100 years for So’o and Nsimi areas, + 2 °C/100 years for Messam area, and + 1.4 °C/100 years for Olama area. Except in autumn, rainfall shows no trend (p > 0.01) at all-time scales and for all 5 areas. In autumn, it shows significant decreasing trend (p < 0.01) in Olama, Mbalmayo and Messam areas. The long-term evolution of Q contrasts with that of AT and rainfall at several points. For example, at Olama, Mbalmayo and Nsimi outlet, the significant increase (p < 0.01) in Q at fortnightly scale contrasts with that in AT and the absence of trend (p > 0.01) in rainfall. At Olama, Mbalmayo and Nsimi outlet, the significant increase (p < 0.01) in spring Q contrasts with that of AT and the absence of a trend (p > 0.01) in rainfall. However, in tributaries, the evolution of Q at certain time scales supports the temperature effect. For example, at Pont So’o, the significant decrease (p < 0.01) in Q at fortnightly scale and in winter agrees with the significant increase (p < 0.01) in AT. Similarly, at Nsimi, the significant decrease (p < 0.01) in Q at fortnightly scale and in summer agrees with the significant increase (p < 0.01) in AT. In addition, the effect of temperature on discharge evolution is considered secondary with respect to the overall results and it is observed on certain tributaries and time scales only. On the other hand, the absence of trend and the significant increase (p < 0.01) observed for the discharge at the main channel stations (Mbalmayo and Olama) shows that the drinking water catchment station located in the town of Mbalmayo does not have effect on the evolution of discharge over the long term. Considering the results obtained on the evolution of rainfall and AT, the increase in discharge over the long term cannot be attributed to climate change. Thus, the only factor that can provide this explanation is the increase in impervious and agricultural surface and the decrease in forest area.

In this study, despite the significant increase in discharge, the values of pH, EC, TDS, and the concentrations of cations and anions, except , , and, to a lesser extent, , significantly increase over the long term at all time scales considered. The increase in these parameters and ions eliminate discharge as a factor influencing their variation. A greater contribution of groundwater to surface water can explain the increase in the concentrations of the above parameters and ions. However, such a contribution should be accompanied by a significant decrease in the concentration of DOC over the long term. Except in spring, all stations show significant or non-significant decreasing trend in DOC over the long term. In winter, DOC shows significant decreasing trend (p < 0.01) at Olama and Pont So’o, when the base flow is observed. In summer, DOC shows significant decreasing trend (p < 0.01) at Pont So’o. In spring, DOC decreases non-significantly at Nsimi outlet, and increases non-significantly for the other four stations. The decrease in DOC affirms groundwater contribution to the increase in the values of the parameters pH, EC, TDS, and the concentrations of cations and anions mentioned above, over the long term. In addition to the contribution of groundwater, anthropogenic activities also influence the increase in physicochemical parameters and concentrations of major ions over the long term. Given the silicate context of the study area, the increase in pH towards a more basic character cannot be explained by the contribution of groundwater, but rather by an influence of anthropogenic activities104. Also, this contribution cannot explain the significant decreasing trend observed for , , and concentrations.

Temporal signature of LULCC and population growth on Nyong river chemistry

LULCC in the UNB results in a replacement of forest and water areas by impervious and agricultural surface. These changes can be attributed to two types of factors: (1) direct factors related to economic profit and (2) indirect factors associated with population increase105. Direct factors include large-scale commercial agriculture (cocoa, palm, coffee) and industrial selective logging. Indirect factors are justified by significative high correlation between LULC classes and population, which is the origin of impervious and agricultural surface expansion through: energy supply, small-scale agriculture for survival (banana, plantain, cassava, peanuts, macabo, etc.), bush fires and the construction of roads and houses for housing and commerce. Bushfires are used to kill trees to create space for crops.

Increases in population and LULCC affect water chemistry in UNB. Like all Cameroonian cities, the localities of the UNB do not have a waste and wastewater management or sanitation system. The waste and wastewater generated increases with the population and it is dumped into the environment and river without control or prior treatment. In addition, the septic tanks are leached towards the river. The increase in impervious and agricultural surface and associated activities is accompanied by an ever-increasing use of agricultural inputs (fertilizers, pesticides, fungicide and herbicides), which can deteriorate water quality. Waste and wastewater also result from activities such as breweries, commerce, livestock farming, fishing, etc. The waste and wastewater produced increase the pollution load in the environment.

Several factors related to LULCC could explain the evolution of elemental concentrations and fluxes over the long term. The significant increase in the concentration of can be attributed to the release of untreated domestic salts into the environment, as observed in the Mekong basin106. The application of potassium chloride fertilizers in agricultural production is a potential source of the significant increase in . The increase in can be associated with waste and wastewater from various industries. can be attributed to the application of inorganic phosphate fertilizers, pesticides and industrial wastes104. The increase in can be associated to open defecation, LULCC, chemical fertilizers, animal waste materials, and untreated sewage resulting from industrial and domestic waste104. Generally, for the five stations, and consistently with increasing concentrations and discharge, specific fluxes to the sea increase significantly with time for , , , , , and .

The overall significant decrease observed for , , Alk, , and , may be associated with increased photosynthetic activity due to eutrophication of the Nyong River107as well as slash-and-burn cultivation. Aquatic phytoplankton (e.g., diatoms) assimilate dissolved inorganic carbon and nutrients (e.g., N, P, ) to synthesize organic compounds108. High N and P loads introduced by human activities into the environment and the river boost photosynthetic activity and consequently increase primary production, resulting in a significant decrease in the value ​​of Alk and concentrations of , , and . This result is consistent with what has been observed in the Mekong River106 and the Yangtze River109but it is contrast to what has been observed in the Mississippi River110. Slash-and-burn agriculture is a common practice in the Nyong, and was expected to influence river water chemistry over the long-term85,111. Indeed, many experimental studies have shown that the first rains following slash-and-burn lead to an increase in the concentration of elements in the water for a few hours to a few days, before falling back to or below the pre-burn level112, 113–114. In the UNB, this practice probably leads to the release of cations and anions which are leached by the first rains from February to March. In the long term, this release leads to the depletion of these chemical elements in the soil, hence the significant decrease (p < 0.01) observed for , , Alk, , and . The significant increase (p < 0.01) in cations and suggests that losses from slash-and-burn are lower than inputs from domestic and industrial waste, as well as agricultural inputs. On the other hand, the significant decrease (p < 0.01) in , , Alk, , and suggests that losses from photosynthesis and slash-and-burn must be greater than contributions from other processes and factors. A third factor that could explain the variation in concentration is a change in the rate of chemical and physical weathering over time106. Indeed, a decrease in the weathering rate over the long term should lead to a decrease in concentration, and vice versa106. However, the deforestation in the Nyong basin, as shown in this study, is likely to accelerate weathering over time115,116. Thus, this third hypothesis is rather unlikely. In addition to the greater contribution of groundwater discussed earlier (see Sect. 5.1), the significant (p < 0.01) long-term decrease in DOC can also be associated with slash-and-burn. This leads to volatization/oxidation by fire of organic litter, which generally contributes to the DOC content in the water113. In the long term, this volatization/oxidation can lead to a decrease in organic litter in the Basin and, therefore, in DOC in the river water. Significant decreasing trend (p < 0.01) in SPM was observed at Olama at the fortnightly scale, in spring and summer, as well as at Pont So’o at the fortnightly and interannual scales and in spring. At Pont So’o, the decreasing in SPM was estimated at −0.3 , and it reflects a lowering in physical erosion, despite the increase in impervious and agricultural surface.

Some parameters and ions showed fluxes whose trends contrasted with those of their original concentrations at monthly, interseasonal and annual scales. This is the case for , , DOC, SPM and, to a lesser extent, . Indeed, these parameters and ions generally showed concentrations whose general trends decreased significantly (p < 0.01) or not (p > 0.01) over the long term (see Sect. 4.6.2). However, the general trends of their fluxes increased significantly (p < 0.01) or not (p > 0.01) over the long term (see Sect. 4.6.3). This contrast is linked to the significant (p < 0.01) increase or not (p > 0.01) over the long term of the corresponding discharge used to calculate the fluxes.

Spatial signature of “LULC and population” distribution on Nyong river chemistry

The spatial variation of water chemistry in the Nyong River shows that it is influenced by LULC composition and population density. Indeed, pH, EC, Alk and major ions show higher average values on the stations of the main channel of the Nyong River (Mbalmayo and Olama) compared to the stations of the tributaries. In addition, the Mbalmayo station displays average concentrations of physicochemical parameters and major ions that are generally higher than those of all stations. The high average values of parameters in Mbalmayo station and Nyong are linked to a high relative population density and impervious and agricultural surface in the city of Yaounde. Yaounde located in Mfoundi Division, is the main city of Nyong and one of the two largest cities in Cameroon. Projections show that the population of Yaounde in 2020 was 3,317,436. Covering an area of 180 (0.9% of the total area of the UNB), Yaounde is host 80.6% of the population of the Nyong basin. The proportion of the area of Yaounde is therefore marginal compared to that of the sheltered population. The waste and wastewater generated by the high population density and industries explains the high values of physicochemical parameters and major ions in Mbalmayo and Olama compared to the tributaries.

Limits and perspectives of the study

This study has several limitations related to: (1) Landsat data, (2) climate data, and (3) the population projection model.

For the LULCC study, Landsat images offer several advantages, namely: their continuous and consistent recording from 1972 to the present day, their global coverage and repeatability, and their free, open, and public access. Their moderate resolution of 30 m is also suitable for studying the temporal evolution of the forest, impervious and agricultural surface in a watershed the size of the Nyong. However, this resolution remains too high to study the evolution of the water surface, which is marginal compared to forest and impervious and agricultural surface. Thus, for a proper study of the evolution of the water surface, 1 m high-resolution data (for example) would be more suitable. However, such data have limited access and are subject to a charge. In addition, such data are recent and therefore do not offer the possibility of studying LULCC over the long term as Landsat data. In addition to resolution, the cloud cover of the Landsat scenes was also a limitation in this study. For example, to create the 2010 LULC map, scenes from 2010, 2011, and 2013 had to be combined (Table 1) due to cloud cover. Thus, the LULCC was necessarily underestimated between 2010 and 2015.

The limitations of climate data lie in both their validity and their spatial resolution. The correlation between observed and satellite data yielded a correlation coefficient of 0.5, suggesting only moderate validity. Based on the spatial resolution of the climate data (0.5°×0.5°), Pont So’o and Olama stations, as well as those of Messam and Nsimi outlet, fell into the same grids. This suggests similar rainfall patterns in the areas of these stations. Although there are no observational data that could confirm or refute this similarity, higher-resolution satellite data could have dispelled any doubt.

The population projection model estimated that the population continued to evolve perfectly as in the past. However, this model suffers from the lack of census data that could allow inclusion of fit statistics and uncertainty quantification. Furthermore, the model also does not take into account internal displacement caused by the security crisis that began in 2016 in the North West and South West regions of Cameroon. Indeed, this crisis led to a significant displacement of populations fleeing insecurity from these regions to other parts of the country. The localities of UNB, and mainly Yaoundé, were necessarily impacted by this displacement, receiving a significant influx of population. This influx likely led to an above-average population growth rate from 2016 onwards.

UNB is the only critical zone of ​​the Central African rainforest with 29 years of hydrological and hydrochemical data. This long-term monitoring has highlighted a significant change in river chemistry and, to a lesser extent, in discharge. This change has been attributed to anthropogenic forcing, notably the conversion of forest to impervious and agricultural land. However, a more comprehensive, robust, and reliable understanding of the functioning of the critical zone would be possible by adding: (1) climate observational data, (2) groundwater data, and (3) very high frequency data. In fact, using of satellite climate data has made it possible to link river chemistry to climate. However, regular monitoring of climate parameters (rainfall, AT, air relative humidity, wind velocity and direction, and global radiation) corresponding to hydrological and hydrochemical data, would allow for more robust and reliable conclusions on the role of climate in water chemistry. In addition to the river, acquiring the same data on groundwater (water level and hydrochemical data) would allow an analysis of the existing interaction between the two compartments. Daily, fortnightly and monthly data already provide a good basis for modelling UNB functioning. For example, using part of the data used here, Komba et al.104 developed a model to predict river chemistry from discharge. However, very high-frequency data (minute to hourly scale) would allow for better validation and calibration of the model.

Conclusion

This study aimed to examine how hydroclimatic factors, demographic growth, and LULCC interact to affect river chemistry in the UNB, a critical humid tropical ecosystem in Central Africa. The results show that between 2005 and 2020, the population increased in UNB from 2.6 million to 4.1 million. This population growth has created demands such as food, housing, agricultural activities, etc. To meet these demands, populations have converted 1,207 of forest into impervious and agricultural surface (buildings, roads, agricultural land, etc.). LULC for forest, impervious and agricultural surface, and water changed as from 2005 to 2020: 17,845 to 16,638 (−6.7%), 1,376 to 2,587 (+ 88%), and 15 to 11 (−26.7%), respectively. Increase in impervious and agricultural surface increased soil sealing, thus promoting increase runoff and discharge, in the long term. Despite the discharge increase, the discharge of household and industrial waste and wastewater into the environment and river led to significant increase (p < 0.01) in pH, EC, TDS, cation and concentrations. Also, it could be due to a greater contribution of groundwater to surface water, as supported by the significant decrease (p < 0.01) in DOC over the long term. The significant decrease in , , Alk, , and was associated with increased photosynthetic activity due to eutrophication of the Nyong River, as well as long term depletion of these chemical elements in the soil by slash-and-burn agriculture. Besides the contribution of groundwater, the significant decrease (p < 0.01) in DOC was also associated with slash-and-burn agriculture which leads to volitization/oxidation of the organic litter that causes it. The significant decrease in SPM (p < 0.01) reflects a decrease in physical impairment in UNB.

At the end of this study, the following recommendations are made for sustainable management of the UNB:

Continue current monitoring to have longer hydrological and hydrochemical observations series;

Combine this monitoring with observations of climate parameters, groundwater level and chemistry, and hydrological and hydrochemical observations on a minute to hourly scale;

Provide the towns in the basin with a system for collecting, recycling and treating the waste and wastewater produced, before releasing them into the environment;

establish a policy for the choice and quantification of agricultural inputs used;

Mitigatedeforestation by reducing the timber trade.

Abstract

This paper introduces an Enhanced Seasons Optimization (ESO) algorithm that significantly enhances the search performance and solution quality of the standard Seasons Optimization (SO) algorithm. The SO shows promising results for numerical and engineering optimization tasks, but has weaknesses in balancing exploitation and exploration, resulting in suboptimal solutions and premature convergence. To address these limitations, the ESO incorporates four key innovations: (i) a root spreading operator which enhances local exploitation, (ii) a wildfire operator that enhances the diversity of population, (iii) refined competition and resistance operators that strengthen solution quality and convergence performance, and (iv) opposition-based learning to avoid local optimums. The effectiveness of the ESO algorithm is examined through a comparative analysis against a diverse set of counterpart optimizers, including foundational and highly cited algorithms (PSO, DE), top-performing algorithms (CMAES, LSHES, RRTO, ALA, THRO), and novel nature-inspired algorithms (SO, HO, CBKA). The set of benchmarks comprises 25 numerical optimization functions and 4 engineering design problems. Statistical results demonstrate that the ESO significantly outperforms the original SO algorithm and exhibits competitive or superior performance compared to the counterpart optimizers regarding convergence performance and solution quality. Our key findings include: (i) ESO is the top-performing algorithm in 16 out of 25 of the numerical functions and 3 out of 4 engineering design problems; (ii) it achieved an average ranking of 3.68 in the Friedman test on all numerical benchmarks, outperforming all counterpart algorithms in solving numerical benchmarks; Meanwhile, the second-ranked THRO algorithm attains the average ranking of 4.5 on all functions; (

iii) ESO generated the best results in shifted and composite numerical functions, and (iv) it obtained the best performance in the scalability analysis test on 1000-dimensional numerical problems.

IntroductionThe foremost objective of optimization is to identify the best solution among a set of feasible solutions to a problem1. The process involves maximizing or minimizing an objective function by altering certain decision variables under various constraints. Typically, real-world problems are complicated, non-differentiable, nonlinear, and involve multiple decision variables and constraints. Meta-heuristics, as well-known stochastic methods, are an excellent approach for tackling real-world numerical and engineering design problems. These methods are distinguished by simplicity, flexibility, adaptability, efficiency, ability to handle non-linearity, global search capability, and derivation-free mechanism2. Although meta-heuristics do not guarantee the finding of optimal solutions for every problem, they are sufficiently flexible to identify near-optimal solutions within a constrained timeframe, especially when addressing complex, large-scale problems3. Challenges associated with meta-heuristics include local optima trapping, premature convergence, and parameter tuning.

Meta-heuristics have found widespread application in addressing engineering optimization problems across diverse domains including agriculture2, electrical engineering3, structural and civil engineering4,5, communication6, health7, smart city planning8, aerospace industry9, financial10, transportation systems11, Internet of Things (IoT)12, tuning machine learning and data mining models13, scheduling and planning14, and many other engineering problems. This broad applicability underscores the versatility and effectiveness of meta-heuristics in dealing with a wide array of complicated engineering problems.

Several comparative studies and survey papers on meta-heuristics are given in15, 16–17. Meta-heuristics can be classified into multiple taxonomies based on various categorization metrics. Two notable categorization metrics include motivation source and the number of solutions18.

Regarding the number of solutions, meta-heuristics can be classified into two groups: single-solution and population-based. In the former group, the algorithm explores the solution space using one solution and refines its quality over some iterations to achieve an optimal solution. Single-solution algorithms are particularly suitable for problems that benefit from depth-oriented search strategies rather than broad exploration, eliminating the need for maintaining a population of solutions. A key limitation of single-solution algorithms is their susceptibility to convergence on local optima. However, they are easy and need a low number of function evaluations. Simulated annealing (SA)19 is the most popular strategy in this category. To address the inherent limitations of single-solution algorithms, population-based meta-heuristics are devised that leverage a diverse set of solutions to enhance the exploration of the search space. The initial population is initialized randomly and updated over generations using population updating operators. These algorithms are efficient choices for large-scale and complex problems. Notable examples are genetic algorithm (GA)20, ant colony optimization (ACO)21, particle swarm optimization (PSO)22, firefly algorithm (FFA)23, and artificial bee colony (ABC)24.

In terms of inspiration sources, meta-heuristics are categorized into four primary classes: those derived from physics and chemistry, biological processes, animal behavior, and human-related phenomena.

Physics and chemistry-inspired algorithms are designed to model natural processes and phenomena such as annealing, gravitational forces, and magnetism. A prominent instance in this category is simulated annealing (SA). Some other notable algorithms in this category include the magnetic optimization algorithm (MOA)25, water cycle algorithm (WCA)26, gravitational search algorithm (GSA)27, thermal exchange optimization (TEO)28, and gyro fireworks algorithm (GFA)29.

Human-inspired meta-heuristics simulate various aspects of human cognition, decision-making processes, social dynamics, and interactions. Election optimization algorithm (EOA)30, cultural algorithm (CA)31, and class topper optimization (CTO) algorithm32 are examples of human-inspired algorithms.

Animal-inspired meta-heuristics draw motivation from the biological characteristics and collective behaviors of creatures such as flocks, insects, mammals, and wolves. Notable algorithms in this domain are ACO21, PSO22, FFA23, ABC24, frigate bird optimizer (FBO)33, fishing cat optimizer (FCO)34, and Tianji’s horse racing optimization (THRO)35.

The motivation of bio-inspired algorithms is the special actions of biological organisms, natural events, and plants. Since nature intelligently solves complex problems, nature-inspired algorithms provide intelligent solutions to complex problems. Examples of such algorithms are GA20, sunflower optimization algorithm (SFO)36, flower pollination algorithm (FPA)37, forest optimization algorithm (FOA)38, tree-seed algorithm (TSA)39, SO1, starfish optimization algorithm (SFOA)40, black-winged kite algorithm (BKA)41, Hippopotamus optimization (HO) algorithm42, snow ablation optimizer (SAO)43, and artificial lemming algorithm (ALA)44. While algorithms like SFO and FPA share a common source of inspiration, their working principles differ. The SFO simulates the heliotropic strategy of sunflowers to find optimal solar orientation, while FPA models the pollination and reproduction behavior of the flowers. FOA is inspired by the seed dispersal mechanisms of trees in forests, aiming to reinforce their lifespan and territory. The algorithm is equipped with local and global seeding operators to facilitate exploitation and exploration within the search space. A similar approach is adopted by the TSA algorithm, which simulates the reproduction behavior of trees through seed propagation. The SO algorithm incorporates four operators, including renew, competition, seeding, and resistance, to mimic the seasonal behaviors of trees. The algorithm performs exploration using seeding and renew operators and exploitation using the competition operator. The SOA43 simulates the melting and sublimation behavior of snow to provide a tradeoff between exploration and exploitation and mitigate the premature convergence.

An interesting trend in contemporary optimization research involves enhancing the performance of existing metaheuristics. This pursuit has resulted in the development of different versions of established algorithms, often differing in their operators and underlying working principles. For instance, the enhanced sine cosine algorithm (EPSCA)45 incorporates a Brownian motion and an elite pool strategy into the standard SCA to enhance the position updating process of the standard SCA. In addition, a local search mechanism and a powerful mutation strategy are developed to reinforce search performance and avoid premature convergence. The Q-learning reinforced JAYA algorithm (QLJAYA)46 incorporates the Q-learning and a gradient search scheme to dynamically balance population diversity and convergence. It also utilizes a covariance matrix learning strategy to improve rotational invariance of JAYA. The hybrid grasshopper optimization algorithm (HGOA)47 integrates enhanced GOA and modified butterfly optimization with probabilistic selection to balance exploration and exploitation mechanisms. HGOA is equipped with a self-adaptive pattern search, centroid opposition-based learning, and a probabilistic selection to improve the exploitation capacity. Xiao et al.48 proposed a multi-strategy boosted snow ablation optimizer (MSAO) to resolve the shortcomings of the standard SOA algorithm, including premature convergence, lack of population diversity, and low convergence accuracy. MSAO incorporates four strategies to enhance the SOA algorithm: a greedy selection for balanced exploitation-exploration; an initial good point set to improve exploration and convergence rate; a differential evolution (DE)49 algorithm to update individual positions for broader search; and a dynamic lens opposition-based Learning (DLOBL) method to prevent local optimal stagnation. The multi-strategy improved slime mould algorithm (MSMA)50 improved the slime mould algorithm (SMA)51 in three folds: (i) a new search equation is proposed to obtain a tradeoff between exploration and exploitation; (ii) a dynamic random search method is used to perform local search and improve the search efficiency, and (iii) an adaptive mutation probability is developed to escape premature convergence. In other work, an enhanced slime mould algorithm (AGSMA)52 is proposed to improve the standard SMA by introducing an efficient learning operator, an adaptive grouping strategy, and an effective search mechanism to provide a balance between population diversity and convergence. An enhanced social learning swarm optimizer (ESLPSO)53 is developed to improve the basic social learning swarm optimizer (SLPSO) algorithm. It uses a non-stagnant distribution assumption, a nonlinear control coefficient, and an interactive learning mechanism to preserve population diversity and provide a balance between convergence speed and population diversity. A hybrid crayfish optimization algorithm with DE (HCOADE)54 enhances the original crayfish optimization algorithm (COA) by integrating DE strategies. This addresses COA’s issues with premature convergence and poor exploration, leading to improved global optimization performance through DE’s mutation and crossover mechanisms. An enhanced walrus optimization algorithm (WaOA)55 improves the optimization performance of the walrus optimization algorithm by introducing an improved initialization strategy and then modifying the fleeing, migrating, and feeding strategies.

In recent years, the field of optimization algorithms has witnessed a large number of new emerging optimization algorithms inspired by natural or man-made processes. Some researchers have addressed the problem of the emergence of new algorithms and have shown that this line of research is under threat56. They believe that the researchers have misunderstood the concept of the “No Free Lunch” theorem in developing new metaheuristic algorithms57. Also, recently, many researchers have critically examined some metaphor-based metaheuristic algorithms such as arithmetic optimization algorithm (AOA)58, chimp optimization algorithm (ChOA)59, whale optimization algorithm (WOA)60, grey wolf optimizer (GWO), moth-flame optimization (MFO), and ant lion optimizer (ALO)57. Researchers reveal some structural bias in the mentioned metaphor-based approach that leads to artificially high accuracy in solving the standard numerical optimization functions, but results in weak performance when applied to shifted and composite numerical optimization benchmarks.

A recent survey16 indicates that approximately 43% of published works introduce novel metaheuristics, while the remaining 57% focus on improving existing algorithms. This trend reveals that the trend is to improve the existing metaheuristics, reflecting a perception that there is a sufficient number of optimization algorithms. While optimization meta-heuristics have a long history and many of the meta-heuristics presented so far and will be presented in the future, this topic is hot and has recently experienced renewed interest. This fact is largely attributed to the “no free lunch (NFL)” theorem61 that asserts there is no single algorithm that can universally solve every problem. Hence, there remains a clear rationale for introducing new optimization algorithms or enhancing existing ones. By reviewing the literature, it was found that a few algorithms have modeled plant behavior, and those algorithms inspired by the behavior of plants have only modeled a limited subset of plant characteristics.

Based on the NFL theorem and the limited modeling of plant behavior in existing optimization algorithms, this work introduces an enhanced seasons optimization (ESO) algorithm for global optimization and engineering design. The proposed ESO improves the standard SO algorithm in five key aspects: (i) a novel wildfire operator to mitigate premature convergence and enhance population diversity; (ii) a root spreading operator to improve exploitation of the solution space; (iii) an enhanced competition operator for further exploitation improvement; (iv) an enhanced resistance operator to effectively model the natural selection through the stochastic elimination of suboptimal solutions; and (v) the integration of opposition-based learning to escape local optima. This work represents a novel contribution to the field, as it introduces the first mathematical models of wildfire and root spreading within an optimization algorithm, as well as the first incorporation of opposition-based learning into the SO algorithm.

The motivations to select the SO algorithm for improvement are due to its self-adaptability, undiscovered potential, and biological plausibility. The SO algorithm has an interesting philosophy. It is based on the natural growth cycle of trees in four seasons of the year (spring renewal, summer competition, autumn seeding, and winter resistance). Its ecological metaphor is consistent with real-world optimization dynamics. The biological operators of SO are more interpretable for engineering systems. It simulates real-world tree dynamics, unlike abstract physics or animal metaphors. SO’s seasonal structure allows a low-cost combination of new operators. Improving the operators of SO can lead to developing a robust optimization algorithm that can dynamically adjust exploitation and exploration. The SO is more interpretable than many other evolutionary algorithms due to its ecological background. It provides richer behavior than other plant-inspired algorithms through modeling the full lifecycle of trees. No other work has addressed the improvement of the SO algorithm, and we intended to develop it in such a way that it can solve numerical and engineering optimization problems with the highest performance. The proposed ESO systematically address the limitations of the SO algorithm while preserving its ecological foundation, making it both empirically robust and theoretically sound.

Overall, this paper presents several key contributions:

Algorithm development: The primary contribution is the development of a boosted seasons optimization (ESO) algorithm. This involves new formalizations of the competition and resistance operators and the introduction of two novel operators: root spreading and wildfire.

Enhanced competition operator: A refined competition operator is introduced to improve the interaction between solutions in the search space, driving solutions toward the global optimum and improving convergence.

Introducing an efficient resistance operator: This operator by stochastic elimination of suboptimal solutions helps the algorithm to reach the global optimum.

Root spreading operator: This operator enhances the exploitation of the algorithm. It creates a hypercube around the best solution and employs a logistic chaotic map for precise exploitation.

Wildfire operator: This operator, inspired by natural forest fires, diversifies tree populations and prevents premature convergence.

Opposition-based learning: The incorporation of this strategy helps the algorithm escape local optima and increases the likelihood of finding the global optimum.

Experimental validation: The ESO algorithm is tested on both numerical and engineering design problems, and compared with counterpart algorithms. The analysis of results demonstrates the superior performance of the ESO compared to existing algorithms, with better convergence and higher solution accuracy.

The paper is organized as follows: Section 2 details the canonical SO algorithm and its mathematical formulation. Section 3 outlines the working principle of the proposed ESO algorithm. Seasons optimization algorithm

General aspects

The Seasons Optimization (SO) algorithm1 emulates the natural growth process of trees throughout the seasonal cycle. This algorithm functions as a multi-agent system, where the search entities are referred to as “trees”. In spring, warmer weather initiates a new growth cycle for trees, allowing them to produce new leaves, flourish, and grow by utilizing sunlight, carbon dioxide, water, and chlorophyll. Seeds from previous seasons also germinate, giving rise to seedlings. Some seedlings endure through the summer, while others may be lost due to shading or overcrowding. Summer is characterized by vigorous growth and root expansion of trees. This season, marked by hot weather and long sunny days, prompts trees to compete for shared resources such as nutrients, water, and light. Such competition can lead to increased mortality rates among trees, significantly influencing their growth patterns. Negative interactions among trees, whether directly or through resource depletion, can exacerbate this phenomenon. Trees situated in favorable geographical habitats receive more resources and thrive, while others may struggle or perish. A tree’s success in this competition relies on its strength, size, crown shape, and growth conditions. During autumn, mild weather results in falling leaves and seed dispersal from various trees, which is a crucial stage in their life cycle. This process affects trees’ population diversity, evolution, dynamics, and invasions. Seeds may fall nearby or be carried to new areas by the wind, animals, water, storms, and flooding, enabling trees to ensure survival and expand their territories. Some seeds await germination in early spring, but many do not sprout due to predation by rodents and birds or unfavorable conditions. In winter, trees enter a state of dormancy, akin to the hibernation observed in some animals, with significantly reduced energy consumption and metabolism. They rely on energy reserves accumulated during the warmer seasons to maintain health rather than engaging in growth. The ability to withstand freezing temperatures is crucial for the survival of trees across diverse ecosystems. Dormant trees with sufficient strength can resume growth in the subsequent spring; conversely, those that are weak, inadequately acclimated, or have experienced various stresses may not survive.

Enhanced season optimization (ESO) algorithm

The standard SO algorithm has demonstrated satisfactory performance in solving both engineering and numerical optimization tasks. However, the algorithm exhibits three critical limitations:

Exploration deficiency: Trapping in local optima for certain problems due to insufficient exploration capability

Exploitation inefficiency: Sub-optimal intensification around promising regions

Diversity degradation: Progressive loss of population diversity after several iterations

To alleviate the above-mentioned defects of the SO, we proposed an enhanced seasons optimization algorithm, referred to as ESO. The proposed algorithm modifies the standard SO algorithm in four ways:

Introduction of the wildfire operator: This operator increases the diversity of the population and assists the algorithm in escaping local optimums.

Introduction of the root spreading operator: This operator efficiently exploits the vicinity of the best-so-far solution to hopefully reach the global optimum.

Proposing a new formulation for competition: This formulation further enhances the exploitation in the solution space.

Proposing a new formulation for resistance: This formulation better refines the population to avoid local optimums.

Integration of the opposition-based learning (OBL): This strategy is embedded within the SO algorithm to facilitate escape from local optima during the search process.

Results and discussions

Counterpart algorithms

The proposal of this work is compared with three categories of meta-heuristics, including

Foundational and highly cited algorithms: particle swarm optimization (PSO)22 and differential evolution (DE)49.

Top-performing algorithms: covariance matrix adaptation evolution strategy (CMAES)85, ensemble sinusoidal incorporated with L-SHADE (LSHES)86, and rapidly-exploring random tree optimizer (RRTO)87.

Novel nature-inspired algorithms: Seasos optimization (SO)1, Hippopotamus optimization (HO)42, complex-valued encoding BKA (CBKA)41, artificial lemming algorithm (ALA)44, Tianji’s horse racing optimization (THRO)35.

In addition to the aforementioned algorithms, the ESO algorithm was also benchmarked against multiple nature-inspired algorithms, specifically the flower pollination algorithm (FPA)37, Forest optimization algorithm (FOA)38, and cuckoo search (CS)63, sunflower optimization (SFO)36 and hazelnut tree search (HTS)18. However, given the substantial differences observed in their overall fitness values relative to the ESO and other algorithms under consideration, a detailed presentation of their simulation results has been omitted from this paper.

According to the experimental instructions specified in the IEEE CEC sharetasks88, 89, 90, 91, 92–93 the algorithms were evaluated using the performance metrics across 51 independent runs per test function, with a unique initial population for each run. Numerical benchmarks

The algorithms were tested using twenty-five single-objective optimization problems of the minimization type. These functions are widely used in the IEEE CEC on single-objective numerical problems to evaluate the meta-heuristics. The employed functions are grouped into five categories:

Group I (unimodal functions F1-F5): This class of functions is employed to investigate the fast-converging speed and exploitation ability of the algorithms.

Group II (multimodal functions F6-F10): Characterized by numerous local optima, this set evaluates the algorithms’ ability to avoid local optima and their capacity for exploration.

Group III (fixed-dimension functions F11-F15): This test set is employed to evaluate the algorithms’ effectiveness in jumping out of local optima and avoiding premature convergence when applied to low-dimensional unimodal and multimodal functions.

Group IV (shifted and composition functions F16-F20): This set is derived from the IEEE CEC 200589 and CEC 201495 and CEC 2018 competitions, investigates the algorithms’ ability to provide an equilibrium between exploration and exploitation.

Group V (modern optimization functions F21-F25): Sourced from the CEC 2022 test suite44, these complex functions are used to comprehensively assess the accuracy, robustness, and reliability of the algorithms.

Performance metrics

To evaluate how well the algorithms performed, two statistical measures were used: the mean and the standard deviation (Std) of the objective function values. Ideally, the mean should match the global optimum of the problem, while the standard deviation should be zero. An increase in the standard deviation signifies a decrease in the algorithm’s reliability. To determine the differences between the results of the algorithms, a non-parametric Friedman test, contrast comparison, and Wilcoxon statistical test were conducted, using a 95% significance level.

Numerical results

The statistical results of the proposed ESO and its counterparts on benchmark functions are detailed in Tables 9-13. The best values are emphasized in bold. The results show that ESO generally achieved superior performance compared to its counterparts. The following points are derived from the results.

Regarding unimodal functions, F5, ESO consistently performs better in both mean outcomes and standard deviations than the other algorithms. For F2 and F3, the best results were reported by the LSHES, and after that, THRO, HO, ESO, CBKA, and RRTO, respectively, generated the best results. For F4, the best performances belong to THRO, CBKA, and ESO, respectively. Regarding F1, the ESO, HO, CBKA, and RRTO generated the best results. Overall, with a negligible difference, ESO reported promising results in unimodal functions, and its performance is comparable to the top-performing algorithms. The results confirm that ESO, THRO, HO, CBKA, LSHES, ALA, and RRTO effectively minimize function values, have good exploitation power and convergence speed, and generate reliable results across runs. The low standard deviation values prove the consistency of the ES, THRO, and CBKA algorithms, which is critical in practical optimization applications.

For multimodal functions, ESO, RRTO, THRO, and CBKA obtained excellent performance on multimodal functions, often achieving the best mean values. In terms of standard deviations, ESO performed better than other algorithms. For function F6, ESO and THRO achieve the best mean, which is significantly superior to other algorithms. ALA performed well for functions F2, F3, and F4, but it failed to find the best solutions for F1 and F5. LSHES also performs well, but ESO is still several orders of magnitude better. The results of SO are close to ESO. For F8 and F9, ESO achieves the best mean values, tying with ALA, CBKA, RRTO, DE, LSHES, CMAES, and SO, and outperforming PSO. The RRTO algorithm achieved the best mean for function F10. After that, the CBKA takes the second rank. The results on multimodal functions confirm that ESO can effectively explore the solution space and avoid local optima.

Regarding the fixed-dimension functions, ESO is the top-performing algorithm. After that, THRO, ALA, CBKA, and HO demonstrated strong performance. RRTO finds the global optimum for functions F11, F12, F13, and F14. Regarding F15, RRTO possesses the fourth rank after ESO and THRO algorithms. The ESO is the best-performing algorithm on F15, with a mean value significantly lower than all other algorithms. Like the ESO, the ALA achieved the best mean on functions F11, F12, and F13. In terms of standard deviation, the best results on F11, F12, and F13 belong to DE, CMAES, LSHES, ALA, and ESO. For F14, the minimum standard deviation is obtained by ESO, THRO, CBKA, and RRTO. For F15, the minimum standard deviation belongs to ESO, LSHES, and THRO. Results proved that the ESO, along with DE, CMAES, LSHES, HO, CBKA, RRTO, ALA, and THRO, is powerful enough to prevent premature convergence to local optima dealing with low-dimensional and fixed-size problems.

The results on Group IV functions reveal that there isn’t a single best algorithm across all functions. THRO, ALA, RRTO, and ESO performed consistently well and best on most problems based on mean and standard deviation compared to other algorithms. The worst results belong to PSO regarding the mean values. DE performed well on F16 and F17, but it is not comparable to ESO on other test functions. ALA and HO performed well on F16, F17, and F18, but their results on F19 are not comparable to the ESO algorithm. CBKA generated poor results on F17, F18, and F19, but its results on F20 are better than ESO algorithm. Overall, the results confirm that the HO, THRO, ALA, RRTO, and ESO are an accurate and reliable strategy in solving complex functions.

Regarding the Group V test set, ESO performed best for functions F21, F22, and F23 regarding the mean metric. The second rank belongs to THRO, which obtained the best mean for functions F21, F22, and F25. ESO generally performs better than or equal to SO in terms of the mean values and shows significantly lower standard deviation across the test functions. HO performed well on F21, F22, and F23 in terms of the mean metric. Overall, ESO demonstrates superior consistency (lower standard deviation) compared to other algorithms on F21 and F22. For F23 and F24, RRTO is perfectly consistent. Compared with RRTO, the ESO appears to be a better optimization strategy for Group V functions due to its better mean values and consistency in most problems. In terms of the mean metric, the ESO generated superior performances than THRO, HO, and CBKA across all functions. However, THRO is more consistent with F25 functions. ESO generally achieves better mean performance values than CMAES and DE across the functions. CMAES and DE demonstrated acceptable performance in terms of standard deviation values. PSO generated poor performances on all functions. The high performance reported by the ESO shows its ability to balance exploitation and exploration in the search process of complex hybrid problems.

Friedman test analysis

Table 14 shows the average and final rank of the comparison algorithms calculated by the Friedman test96. The mean fitness values are used to calculate the ranks of algorithms. The results confirm that the ESO ranked highest, indicating its superior performance and robustness on test functions. ESO’s overall rank of 1 confirms its dominance across the entire test set F1-F25. THRO and HO followed in second and third place, respectively. THRO and HO provide consistent, middle-of-the-pack performance. RRTO shows more variance in performance among different groups. THRO achieves a top rank in Group IV, but performs significantly worse in the Group II test set. The effectiveness of RRTO is dependent on the specific characteristics of the optimization problems. Across all categories (F1-F25), ALA obtained the average rank of 5.64 and ranked fifth in terms of the final ranking. CBKA demonstrates an average ranking of 5.92 and a final ranking of 7. While its performance is adequate, it generally underperforms in comparison to ESO, THRO, ALA, HO, and RRTO. For Group I, F1-F5 function, LSHES generated promising results, achieving the second rank. However, its performance diminishes in Groups II and III, suggesting it may not be well-suited for multi-modal and fixed-dimension problems compared to other algorithms. Convergence analysis

To evaluate the convergence performance of the optimizers, we conduct a test using five representative functions: F5, F6, F11, F20, and F25. These functions were chosen to span diverse optimization landscapes, encompassing unimodal, fixed-dimension, multimodal, shifted and rotated, and composite function characteristics. Figure 4 visualizes a graphical representation, along with the convergence plots and solution distributions for the test functions. Examination of the convergence results reveals that the ESO effectively avoids premature convergence. Furthermore, ESO demonstrates a comparatively consistent convergence rate compared to its counterpart optimizers across the tested functions. This enhanced performance is attributable to the algorithm’s proficient balance of exploration and exploitation, coupled with effective local optima avoidance mechanisms. Analysis of the solution distributions, as visualized by box-and-whisker plots, indicates that ESO often generated solutions with minimum variance, thereby substantiating its robust stability in the optimization process.

For function F5 as a representative of unimodal functions, except RRTO, all algorithms demonstrate consistency in convergence performance. The proposed wildfire, seeding, and competition operators provide a proper balance between exploitation and exploration concurrently during their search, which results in consistent convergence for the unimodal function F5. The ESO, SO, CBKA, THRO, and LSHES algorithms’ solution distribution outperformed other algorithms. Regarding the solution distribution, LSHES, SO, CBKA, THRO, and ESO algorithms appear to be the best performers, with very low median objective function values and small spreads, indicating consistent performance.

For the F6 function, ESO demonstrates faster convergence compared to other algorithms. This is attributed to its effective exploration of the search space and ability to escape local optima. As illustrated in the box-and-whisker plot for F6, THRO and ESO produce solutions with the best distribution among the algorithms evaluated. HO, LSHES, CBKA, and ALA are in the next ranks in terms of solution distribution.

Regarding test case F11, the SO, THRO, and ESO algorithms prevent premature convergence by thoroughly exploring the solution space before settling on a final solution. In fixed-dimension test cases, effective algorithms must prioritize exploration to escape local optima. The ESO demonstrates this capability, achieving a compact distribution of solutions that remains competitive in performance. The vast majority of algorithms (DE, CMAES, LSHES, SO, RRTO, CBKA, ALA, THRO, ESO) have fitness distributions clustered very close to zero. This suggests that they are all finding acceptable solutions to the F11 problem. PSO is distinctly worse than the other algorithms. HO appears to have a very low median but has at least one outlier with a higher fitness value. It is therefore less stable than other algorithms.

In addressing the test function F20, the THRO, ALA, CBKA, HO, and after that, ESO and RRTO demonstrated superior convergence performance compared to competing algorithms. The exploration phase provided by seeding and fire operators enables ESO to avoid stagnation, while later-stage exploitation enhances precision. In contrast, DE, PSO, and CMAES proved susceptible to premature convergence in local optima, highlighting ESO’s robustness in balancing global search capabilities with localized refinement.

Regarding the test function F25, THRO and after that ESO demonstrate superior performance, achieving accelerated convergence rates relative to other algorithms. The THRO and ESO yield the most compact solution distribution among comparative algorithms, underscoring their precision in navigating complex search spaces. These outcomes validate the efficacy of THRO and ESO as robust methodologies for addressing intricate optimization problems, particularly those characterized by nonlinear or high-dimensional landscapes.

Conclusions

This research introduced an enhanced seasons optimization algorithm designed for global optimization. The proposed ESO was developed to alleviate the limitations of the standard SO algorithm in population diversity, premature convergence, and exploration-exploitation balance. The ESO builds upon the SO algorithm through four primary enhancements: (i) the introduction of a wildfire operator, which eliminates suboptimal solutions, thereby facilitating exploration of promising regions in the solution space and aiding in the avoidance of local optima; (ii) the introduction of a root spreading operator to exploit the vicinity of the best-so-far solution, (iii) proposing a novel formulation for the competition operator that effectively captures the interactions among trees, thereby enhancing exploitation in promising regions; and (iv) incorporating an opposition-based learning mechanism to escape local optima, and (v) developing a new formulation for resistance operator to effectively model the winter effect on the forest and remove weak trees. Collectively, by embedding mathematical refinements (chaotic local search and OBL), ecological-inspired operators (wildfire, root spreading), and refinements of competition and resistance operators, ESO maintains a robust equilibrium between exploitation and exploration, allowing for gradual convergence toward the global optimum. The proposed ESO and its counterparts are tested on 25 unconstrained optimization benchmarks (unimodal, multimodal, shifted, and composition problems) and 4 constraint engineering design problems (REBD, PVD, WBD, and SRD). The statistical results demonstrated the ESO’s superiority over its counterparts in terms of achieving the global optimum and solution quality. The superiority of the ESO was also confirmed by the Wilcoxon signed-rank test and the contrast estimation. The analysis revealed that ESO obtained the 1st rank in the Friedman test, outperforming the competitors. It is the top-performing algorithm in 15/25 numerical benchmarks and all 4 engineering design problems. ESO generated superior convergence performance and solution distribution in most problems. The tests also proved the stability and scalability of the ESO in 1000-dimensional test functions.

The ESO is simple, robust, and efficient, but it faces two limitations. First, it may encounter challenges related to computational complexity on large-scale problems, e.g., computationally expensive or high-dimensional optimization functions. This issue leads to increased execution time compared with simpler (but inefficient) algorithms like GA and PSO. Second, similar to all other optimization meta-heuristics, the performance of ESO depends on optimal parameter tuning, and which sub-optimal choice of parameters may compromise its performance and convergence speed. Meanwhile, the ESO has reduced the parameter setting compared to the standard SO algorithm. To address these limitations, the following research directions are outlined:

Reducing the time complexity of the ESO algorithm by improving its operators to be able to work with large-scale and complicated optimization tasks.

Developing a self-adaptive version of ESO to automatically configure parameters and minimize user intervention.

Developing a multi-objective version of the ESO for Pareto-based optimization problems.

ESO exhibits robust performance and stability in solving the CEC numerical test suite and engineering design applications. Future research involves evaluating the robustness and scalability of the ESO by applying it to a wide range of practical optimization tasks across various scientific and engineering domains.

Natural processes and the interactions of different organisms play a fundamental role in the life cycle of trees. Modeling complex processes of nature and organisms (e.g., flooding and diseases of trees) could further improve the performance of the algorithm and facilitate its applicability.

2024 JUN 11 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Climate Change Daily News -- New research on climate change is the subject of a new report. According to news reporting from the Universitas Sriwijaya by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Land and forest fires in peatland areas in Indonesia have a widespread negative impact on surrounding communities."


Financial supporters for this research include Cifor-icraf.
Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Universitas Sriwijaya: "Possible vulnerabilities relate to economic, social, ecological, livelihoods, and environmental vulnerability. This study aimed to assess household vulnerability due to land and forest fires in peatland areas in Ogan Komering Ilir District in South Sumatra and observe changes in peat ecosystems in those areas. The study was conducted in three peatland hydrological units (PHUs)-(1) PHU Sungai Sugihan-Sungai Lumpur; (2) PHU Sungai Sibumbung-Sungai Batok; and (3) PHU Sungai Saleh-Sungai Sugihan-covering 300 households as samples. Primary data were collected through structured interviews and analyzed descriptively."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The analysis revealed the following: (1) PHU Sungai Sibumbung-Sungai Batok had the highest score for livelihood vulnerability and climate change but the lowest score for social, economic, and ecological vulnerability; (2) PHU Sungai Saleh-Sungai Sugihan had the highest score for economic and ecological vulnerability but the lowest score for livelihood vulnerability; (3) PHU Sungai Sugihan-Sungai Lumpur had the highest score for social vulnerability but lowest score for climate change vulnerability; and (4) the number of household members, toddlers, and elderly, and all economic indicators except land ownership, contributed relatively similarly to social vulnerability in all PHUs."
For more information on this research see: Farm Household Vulnerability Due to Land and Forest Fire in Peatland Areas in South Sumatra. Land, 2024,13(5):642. (Land - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/land). The publisher for Land is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/land13050642.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Muhammad Yazid, Department of Agribusiness, Faculty of Agriculture, Universitas Sriwijaya, Inderalaya 30662, Indonesia. Additional authors for this research include Dessy Adriani, Riswani, Dini Damayanthy.

urn:contentItem:6DYV-KP83-RRP9-62CB-00000-00Telkom University Researchers Update Current Study Findings on Information Technology (Leveraging Social Media Data for Forest Fires Sentiment Classification: A Data-Driven Method)2025-01-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:18:49ZLexisNexisINFORMATION TECHNOLOGYTelkom University Researchers Update Current Study Findings on Information Technology (Leveraging Social Media Data for Forest Fires Sentiment Classification: A Data-Driven Method)


2025 JAN 24 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Information Technology Daily -- Researchers detail new data in information technology. According to news originating from Bandung, Indonesia, by NewsRx editors, the research stated, "The rise in forest fires over the last two years, which is due to rise in dry weather conditions and human activities, have greatly impacted an area of 1.6 million hectares, leading to significant ecological, economic, and health issues, hence the need to improve disaster response strategies. Previous research determined the lack of coverage regarding public response during forest fires with conventional methods such as satellite images and sensor data."


Our news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Telkom University: "However, social media platforms provide real-time information generated by users, along with location information of disaster events. Sentiment analysis helps in understanding the public reactions and responses to natural disasters, thereby increasing awareness about forest fires. The purpose of this research is to assess the efficiency of Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) method in classifying sentiment for social networks in regard to forest fires. This research aims to examine the effect of TF-IDF, unigram, and the FastText features on the effectiveness of the classification of sentiment. The precision, recall, and F1 score of 2, 3, and 4 determined in the LSTM models with commonly available sentiment analysis tools, such as the Vader Sentiment Analysis and SentiWordNet was used to evaluate the performance of the model. With an improvement of roughly 10%, the four layers of the LSTM model generated the best performance for the evaluation of sentiments about forest fires. The LSTM model with FastText achieved F1, recall and precision scores of 0.649, 0.641, and 0.659, which exceeds lexicon-based method including SentiWordNet and Vader."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The experimental results showed that the LSTM model outperformed lexicon-based methods when used to analyse the tweets related to forest fire. Additional research is required to integrate rule-based models and LSTM models to develop a more robust model for dynamic data."
For more information on this research see: Leveraging Social Media Data for Forest Fires Sentiment Classification: A Data-Driven Method. Journal of Information Systems Engineering and Business Intelligence, 2024,10(3):392-407. The publisher for Journal of Information Systems Engineering and Business Intelligence is Universitas Airlangga.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.20473/jisebi.10.3.392-407.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Warih Maharani, Telkom University, Bandung, Indonesia. Additional authors for this research include Hanita Daud, Noryanti Muhammad, Evizal Abdul Kadir.

urn:contentItem:6FBX-2S53-RSXD-8285-00000-00New wildfire institute takes aim at growing fire crisis2025-03-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:18:49ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1New wildfire institute takes aim at growing fire crisis

If Utah needs to sidestep a major, deadly fire, Utah State University will play a crucial role.

The Utah Forest Restoration Institute, housed in USU's S.J. & Jessie E. Quinney College of Natural Resources, was launched using state funding in 2024 to synthesize science on forest health, develop a resource hub, monitor vegetation shifts and train students in modern practices. It emphasizes curbing the escalating fire threat through research and teamwork with state and federal agencies.

"Fire is a natural part of our ecosystems, and without that regular fire, we've had a lot of changes to our forests," said Larissa Yocom, director of UFRI.

Wildfires burned 8.9 million acres across the U.S. last year, a figure reported in a Feb. 2 Statista publication, marking a more than threefold increase from the previous year. In Utah alone, state data shows 50,170 of those acres were scorched.

"We have a century of fuel buildup in our forests because we've been suppressing fire for decades when, in fact, most of our forests are fire-adapted," Yocom said.

Utah saw 961 fires in 2024, of which 57% were human-caused. Logan's hillsides remain among the most vulnerable areas in the state.

"Sometimes people don't like to hear about it, but climate change is another big thing," Yocom said. "Even if we didn't have that buildup of fuels, we also have hotter, drier seasons, and something that's just indisputable is that our fire seasons are getting longer."

The unpredictability of wildfires only heightens the fear they inspire.

"No city is safe from wildland fire," said Robert LaCroix, assistant chief of fire operations for the Logan City Fire Department.

LaCroix, who brings 33 years of experience battling blazes from California to Utah, was "on the initial attack" of the 2018 Paradise fire, which killed 85 and became the deadliest forest fire in a century. After moving to Utah four years ago, he now leads firefighting efforts in Logan.

Yet, beyond the immediate terror of flames, Utah faces deeper, more complex issues regarding its fire-prone landscapes.

"We have challenges, including understanding exactly what management tools we can use in some of our forests in Utah," Yocom said. "They're different than states around us."

She pointed to the delicate balance of implementing solutions like prescribed fire - a valuable tool that mimics natural burns but often unnerves the public.

"How do we increase public support for prescribed fire, which tends to make people nervous?" Yocom said. "Or for land management agencies doing more thinning? Taking some trees out - that could help - but people sometimes don't like to see that in their forests."

Air quality adds another layer of difficulty. "Smoke from prescribed fires is bad for vulnerable populations," Yocom noted, highlighting the trade-offs that complicate these efforts.

This is where UFRI steps in, offering a path forward through collaboration and open dialogue.

The initiative serves as a hub for federal agencies like the U.S. Forest Service, state bodies such as the Utah Department of Natural Resources, tribes, counties, landowners and local fire services.

"It's a really good chance to bring people together in a more organized way to not step on any toes but to facilitate what others are already doing," Yocom said. "Lots of people are really doing neat, awesome, necessary work already. So, how can we add to it?"

With an April meeting planned to align these groups, UFRI aims to join the Southwest Ecological Restoration Institutes network - alongside Arizona, New Mexico and Colorado - through U.S. Senate Bill 457 and Utah House Bill 1045.

The Logan City Fire Department is among those eager to partner with UFRI.

"I'm excited they got the funding and that it's here at Utah State in our backyard, and we are excited to collaborate," LaCroix said.

He emphasized the value of this local resource for his team, noting the department is looking forward to tapping into UFRI's expertise and training opportunities to bolster their efforts against the growing wildfire threat.

However, firefighting alone can't address the root causes intensifying these blazes.

"A lot of people don't connect to this, but it's integrally connected - climate change," said Patrick Belmont, USU hydrology professor. "Every bit of carbon pollution put in the air from now makes the wildfire problem worse."

In a Feb. 5 Salt Lake Tribune piece following the Los Angeles fires, which killed 29 and destroyed over 16,000 structures, Belmont stressed the urgency of this link.

"I know that's a super polarized term now, but that can't be a reason not to talk about it," Belmont said. "Climate change is complicated, but what it boils down to is we've got to get the fossil fuels turned off as quickly as possible."

Yocom expressed gratitude to the Utah Legislature for recognizing wildfire's urgency with funding that launched UFRI.

"They've decided this is a priority," she said, highlighting their commitment as a driving force behind the institute's mission.

UFRI aims to tackle fuel buildup and public perception gaps.

"That's one of our top priorities," Yocom said. "Making sure that we are focusing not just on our ideas of what needs to happen but really listening to everyone else too."

As wildfires grow fiercer and more frequent, UFRI invites Utahns to confront the unknown together, turning fear into informed resolve.

"Being very clear about how to not make the problem worse moving forward - we need a lot more communication," Belmont said. "My hope would be that it continues to pull together a wide variety of people, not just foresters, not just wildfire people per se, but the wildfire problem is linked to all these other problems."

urn:contentItem:6DD1-7WD1-DYJT-212K-00000-00Man charged in 'Shotgun' wildfire2024-11-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:18:49ZLexisNexisCLASSIFIEDSPg. B3Man charged in 'Shotgun' wildfireMichelle Myers (Staff Writer)

As hundreds of acres continue to burn, a man is in custody and accused of starting the fire near Six Flags Great Adventure, one of several drought-related wildfires in New Jersey.

Richard Shashaty, 37, of Brick Township, is charged with arson and firearms violations after allegedly firing prohibited Dragon's Breath shards linked to what authorities are calling the "Shotgun Fire" in Jackson Township.

On Wednesday, Jackson Township first responders were called to the Central Jersey Rifle Range for a fire that would devour about 350 acres in less than a week, officials said.

"The fire was caused by magnesium shards of a Dragon's Breath 12-gauge shotgun round igniting available combustibles on the berm of the shooting range. The firing of this type of incendiary or tracer ammunition is prohibited in the State of New Jersey," law enforcement and forest fire officials said in a statement.

The fire is presumed to have started in the southwest corner of the rifle range, according to the statement by the Ocean County Prosecutor's Office Major Crime Unit-Arson Squad, New Jersey Forest Fire Service, and the New Jersey State Fire Marshal's Office. It resulted in 15 structures being evacuated and the closure of Stump Tavern Road.

On Saturday, Shashaty turned himself in at the Jackson Township Police Department headquarters, accompanied by his attorney, officials said. He was transferred to the Ocean County Jail, where he awaits a detention hearing.

The Shotgun Fire is just one of multiple wildfires across New Jersey. Heavy smoke from fires in South Jersey, including the Pheasant Run fire in Gloucester County and the Bethany Run Wildfire in Burlington and Camden Counties, prompted Philadelphia's Office of Emergency Management to issue a warning Sunday morning to "use precaution if outdoors and close doors and windows."

In Camden County, Commissioner Jonathan Young issued a statement early Sunday afternoon saying some residents "may have woken up to the smell of smoke and seen small flickers of ash" from the fires burning throughout South Jersey. He said the 360-acre Bethany Run fire on the Voorhees and Evesham border was contained over the weekend, but that other fires throughout the state, including one in West Milford, Passaic County, involving 2,500 acres, might continue to carry "the smell and ash our way" but stressed that "Camden County is not under any threat."

In Pennsylvania's Berks County, Sunday marked the third day in a row that firefighters battled the Neversink Mountain fire near Reading. That fire forced some evacuations through Saturday morning and resulted in a non-fire-related injury to a firefighter.

Through these fires, rain has been the missing hero. Close to 88% of the contiguous United States is considered "abnormally dry" by the interagency U.S. Drought Monitor.

Rain in the forecast for Sunday evening would end Philadelphia's record six-week dry run, but don't expect it to last. The dryness is expected to resume soon after.

Staff writer Anthony R. Wood contributed to this article.
